A primary focus is the bombing program against London. Larson keeps an eye on the logistics of Churchill’s life as well as those of the British war effort. He also invests a lot of attention toward the personal and social lives of these key players and makes extensive use of personal journals to keep the focus on the human impact of the war.

The book helped to explain the development of technologies, ideas, and various conflicts. One thread that I found particularly helpful to trace was America’s involvement in offering aid to Great Britain. While week by week hundreds of civilians are being bombarded and dying, American aloofness must have been agonizing to Churchill and the British populace. Also agonizing must have been the wait for the Lend Lease Act to be passed. This act, which I had only known in name prior to my reading, allowed America to leverage its resources with repayment assured only for damaged property. Larson used the analogy of lending a neighbor a hose when his house is on fire. You don’t sit down and negotiate the terms and cost of hose usage, you give him the hose. Then, if it is burned up in the firefight, you can talk remuneration after the fire has been doused. So too would the Lend Lease Act make some of America’s resources available to our British allies.

In reading the book, aside from specific actions on specific days, I didn’t learn much new information about Churchill. A great orator, indefatigable, an embracer of life, a drinker, a man with a temper, stalwart, a bit of an eccentric. Some interesting tidbits were sprinkled throughout such as his proclivity for working from the bathtub and the bed, but no deeper, heretofore unknown depths of character were uncovered.

Having read two other books by Larson, Devil in the White City and Thunderstruck, I was glad to find a better organized story in this book. Chronology was clear and themes developed slowly but organically. Overall, I am left with a clearer understanding of Churchill as a man and military leader and a greater appreciation for the human impact of war. In the midst of truly prodigious bombing, the citizens of Great Britain carried on with their lives, withstood, endured. It seemed that every person, in one way or another, paid a terrible price and yet the result was triumph in the face of evil.

GRADE: B+
titles: A Man in the Midst of War

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
The Splendid and the Vile is a recounting of the hectic first year of Winston Churchill's Prime Ministership, from May 1940 to May 1941. As I hope most readers already know, Churchill took office at a moment of extreme challenge for the British Empire, when Nazi Germany had conquered most of Europe. Over the next year Churchill guided his nation through innumerable perils, as bombs flattened cities and killed thousands while a badly outnumbered but valiant air force fought back against a seemingly all powerful foe.

This is a tale which has been told many times before, but it always bears recounting, especially at the hands of such a masterly story teller as Erik Larson, who is well known for creating works of history that read like the most sensational fiction. Here Larson portrays Churchill not only as the indomitable war leader but also as a harried husband and father, dealing with a wayward son and daughter in law, a teenage daughter, a loving but mercurial wife, and a lifetime habit of lavish spending that his income could not support. Churchill the crafty diplomat and Machiavellian is also well depicted, especially in Larson's recountings of the Prime Minister's efforts to convince the US President (another Machiavellian) to bring his country into the war. We also get personal views of what life was like during the Blitz and the Battle of Britain from the memoirs and other accounts of countless numbers of ordinary Londoners, along with asides from the German leadership's own point of view.

Larson's research is thorough, making use of archives in the US and Europe as well as many published accounts. His writing is vivid and colorful, with a keen eye for anecdotes like those recounting the amount of work Churchill did while soaking in bathtubs or when, shortly after Pearl Harbor during a visit to the White House, he had a lengthy conversation with FDR while nude. If after reading The Splendid and the Vile you would like to learn more about Churchill, Roosevelt, and the period,I can do no better than to recommend Doris Kearns Goodwin's No Ordinary Time and Lynne Olson's Citizens of London, Last Hope Island, and Those Angry Days.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Maybe I am unique considering all the 5 star reviews, but I did not enjoy this book at all. The author makes a few mistakes: (1) he tends to go too deep into specific archaic elements of the story, (2) he does not do a good job explaining the context of the blitz, and (3) he doesn't develop any characters well including Churchill.

The first in my mind is the biggest issue. Diving into his study, the author goes into sometimes excruciating detail to explain mind-numbing facts about different characters during the time, the frustration of the Germans, the reluctance of the Americans. In addition, he spends a lot of time repeating himself which leaves me as a reader frustrated and bored.

The second is, the author is completely laser focused on 1940 and 1941, and in addition just the Blitz without getting into much detail on the context of the war. Ultimately the book lacks the breadth and sense of drama that would make it interesting, going too deep on depth.

Finally, and most tragically, the author does not do a good job explaining any of the characters well, including Churchill. He often focuses on the "What" and the "How" when it comes to any character actions instead of the "Why". This makes the book very tedious indeed.
titles: Tedious, very slow moving and hard to follow

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: “The Splendid and the Vile A Saga of Churchill …” by Larson was an excellent and entertaining way to understand or review the lessons of how the Allies began to win World War II and the role that Churchill played especially before the US was fully engaged in the War. With well-sourced quotations throughout the book one clearly sees Churchill’s courage, inspirational leadership, his oratory skills and his keen ability to recruit talented individuals and upset the status quo of the entrenched bureaucracy. Besides required gruesome descriptions of the bombing and carnage, the book has fascinating details including things like: how Hess, the third highest Nazi, escaped to Scotland, how the censors operated and the inability of the UK intelligence service to estimate the size of the German Luftwaffe; moreover, the inability of the Brits could to estimate the number of RAF planes in operational condition at any given time even while massively increasing aircraft production vital to the War effort. Incidental to Churchill’s success was his ability to deal with his drinking, his own quirky behaviors and a soap opera of salacious behaviors going on as a back story to winning the war in Europe. This book is highly recommended as a different insight to Churchill and his role in winning WWII.
titles: Excellent and entertaining way to review the lessons of how the Allies began to win World War II

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Firstly I need to say I think all of Erik Larson's other books are masterpieces, so I was expecting more of the same when I pre-ordered 'The Splendid and the Vile' by which I mean a book with at least two, if not more parallel plots tracing various individuals' stories until they coalesce in some kind of grande denouement.
Unfortunately with this book Mr Larson chose a topic and individual(s) about which so many books have been written that, from my point of view, there was no grand revelations or surprises. Churchill, WW2, and various members of the German high command were covered in Mr Larson's normal superb writing style and interwoven as he does so consummately. But ultimately there was very little new to be said or revealed-it's all been done before, many times.
As an entertaining and concise history of all the characters, their connections and involvement in WW2 it was first class, but no great climax or finale, because we all know what happened.
His previous books have combined high profile events with interwoven personal stories, many of which have not been written about before (ie mass murderers and the Chicago World Fair), here was material which has been so well and frequently documented that nothing new of any real consequence was revealed.
I suppose I should say that for those who know little about Winston Churchill, his involvement with WW2 and some the role of his German protagonists, this would be a great primer.
Sorry Mr Larson, but this one was something of a disappointment.
titles: Not what I expected from this author.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
This book focuses on Churchill and his family in 1940 and 1941, the two most challenging and most exciting years of his wartime service as Prime Minister.

Special attention is given not only to policy matters, but also to one of the Prime Minister's official secretaries, Jock Colville; to Churchill's daughter Mary; and to Professor Lindemann, Churchill's eccentric and opinionated scientific advisor.

Appropriately, much attention is devoted to "The Blitz" of English cities by the Nazi Luftwaffe.

I have read many Churchill biographies but found this format, with its focus on 1940 and 1941, preferable to spending so much time on Churchill's early life.

This book provides the reader with many anecdotes about daily life with and around Churchill---very challenging for those in military leadership. The author also spends a considerable amount of time exploring the abrasive, obnoxious, and strangely effective wartime stewardship of Lord Beaverbrook (formerly a mere newspaper magnate) over the production of fighter planes.

Highly recommended! This book takes you back to a time of real crisis when a nation stood alone against the might of Nazi Germany without any certainty that the United States would enter the war. Churchill's leadership was surely the difference between those who wished to succumb to Germany's continental victories and enter into a peace with Hitler (at great cost, no doubt), and those who desired to fight on against the might of Nazi Germany (also at great cost). As Churchill opined at the time to his advisors, nations which go down fighting rise again; those that surrender, are finished. Churchill won the day; the Germans never did invade England; and because Great Britain held on in 1940 and 1941, the invasion of France and the eventual defeat of Hitler's Germany later became possible after America entered the war, using England as a forward logistics and bombing base.

My only criticism of the book is that the author did not focus upon the Argentia Conference off Newfoundland, where FDR and Churchill met secretly at sea in August of 1941; but that subject has been covered in many other books.
titles: One of the Better Churchill Books

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: It takes much talent to write a book about a person and time that were searched and told so intensively during the ages and Erik Larson surely got this talent. Same as with another book of him that i read (the Devil in the White City), he shows his talent of taking real stories and transforming them into vivid, page-turning thrillers. This book portraits the first year of Churchil's as Britain's prime minister, which surely was the most challenging and depressing year any British prime Minister has ever experience. Through the details of the day to day life in Britain those days and details of Churchil and the British government's work during this time, the author was successful in reflecting the real life at one hand and the critical occurrences and decisions of these days on the other hand. It shows Chuchil at its greatest moments as the nation leader while presenting his human, not always perfect, features and characteristics. Only after reading this book one could really understand the gravity of Britain's situation in this eventful days and one could not underestimate Churchil's courage and genius in leading the nation and crafting the faithful decisions and policies that saved Britain and led to the defeat of the Natzi monster.
titles: Great tale of exceptional person at exceptional times

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
This is not a scholarly book but reads more like an extended magazine about life in London during Maj 1940 - May 1941. Erik Larson tells a personal story about WSC himself and his family and people surrounding him. Colleges, acquaintances, some of his current 'friends' and staff. The first 30% is interesting but then it gets repetitive. The ending is good though. Larson's 'In the Garden of Beasts' about family life in Berlin just before the War is way better and more ominous.

I recommend "Churchill: A life" by Martin Gilbert and "Churchill: Walking with Destiny" by Andrew Roberts

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Read this book and contrast the events in it with what you read in the paper or hear on the news currently. The book describes how a strong leader assembles a team of the professionals and not only lets them, but also encourages them, to "do their thing." It also describes how in the time of national crisis an effective leader unites the country and focuses on the greatest threat to it. Critique is accepted but solutions and results were expected.
The use of Britain's war powers act to expedite the production of essential materials (ships, planes, armament, et. al.) was not only quickly implemented but also efficiently managed.
The parts about Churchill's daughter left me wondering "who cares" and that is why I knocked it down one star.
In any respects I am sorry I read this book in March 2020 because it highlighted for me how inept the US leadership is.
If you like this book I would recommend "arsenals of Democracy"

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Book is not set up for Kindle. Book locks up at the 63% mark (chapter 7) so now I cannot finish the book. Total rip off since I am past the return window. How convenient. Way to go Amazon.
titles: Sucks on Kindle, waste of money

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
At the age of sixty-five, Winston Churchill achieved his lifelong dream, becoming Prime Minister of the United Kingdom on May 10, 1940. Less than a year into World War II, Britain was on the brink of defeat:

** The British public, its military leaders, and Churchill himself lived in fear, day after day, of an imminent Nazi invasion.

** France was barely more than a month away from surrendering to the Nazis.

** German U-boats were sinking merchant ships far faster than the country could replace them, threatening the people of the British isles with starvation.

** On the Continent, the British Expeditionary Force was encircled by German forces, retreating toward the French coast and facing almost certain annihilation.

Was an aging alcoholic up to the job?

Yet somehow the aging Prime Minister—an alcoholic with a reputation for questionable judgment—mobilized the British people despite what so many were convinced was a hopeless fight against the Nazi juggernaut. Both King George VI and some of Churchill’s colleagues in the Cabinet were skeptical that he was up to the job. Regardless, through sheer force of will and an unparalleled gift for stirring rhetoric, Churchill led his nation virtually alone in the world for eighteen months before the United States finally entered the war.

Churchill’s lofty rhetoric is familiar to anyone with even a passing acquaintance with the Second World War. His speeches are often quoted to this day on both sides of the Atlantic. In The Splendid and the Vile, Larson reveals what is often missing from accounts of those addresses.

The backstory for Churchill’s legendary speeches

For example, many are familiar with his ringing speech to Parliament promising to “fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender—” But Larson adds, “As the House roared its approval, Churchill muttered to a colleague, ‘And . . . we will fight them with the butt end of broken bottles, because that’s bloody well all we’ve got.” Larson also reports that this speech, which Churchill read on BBC Radio that evening, received little attention from the public. Many who listened thought he sounded drunk. In fact, Larson reveals, he read the speech with a cigar in his mouth.

The result was problematic. “Home Intelligence reported that only two newspapers ‘gave Churchill’s speech headline value’ and that the speech had done little to fortify the public.” But the author implies that this lack of attention was of little consequence to the Prime Minister because “the audience Churchill had mainly in mind when he crafted his speech was, once again, America.” It’s details like this that make Larson’s account so hard to forget.

How did the man manage day to day in the midst of the Blitz?

The story of Churchill’s courage and his brilliant if unorthodox leadership style is well known. What is less well known is how he managed from day to day to persist in the face of such overwhelming odds during that critical first year of his five years in office. And that’s the story Erik Larson tells, and tells so well, in The Splendid and the Vile.

Historians typically zero in on the stuff of politics and policy, and in wartime on the ebb and flow of battle. Not so Erik Larson, one of the most outstanding popular historians writing today in the English language. While all that is present in The Splendid and the Vile, Larson’s focus is on the emotional reality of life in and around 10 Downing Street during that fateful year. He vividly conveys a sense of what it would have been like to be Winston Churchill or a member of his inner circle or his family. As he writes in the book’s acknowledgments, “I set out to hunt for the stories that often get left out of the massive biographies of Churchill, either because there’s no time to tell them or because they seem frivolous. But it is in frivolity that Churchill often revealed himself.”

Private diaries cast light on Winston Churchill in WWII

Larson draws largely on diaries written by his private secretaries and his then eighteen-year-old daughter Mary. He also leans heavily on contemporaneous accounts from an official research effort called Home Intelligence and a privately organized research program called Mass-Observation. Both of the latter employed hundreds of individuals throughout society to record their observations in diaries on a daily basis. Larson offers us an intimate look at the lives they all lived while thousands of tons of German bombs rained down all around them, day after day after day, and Churchill helped set the world’s future course. And he leavens his tale with accounts of the German perspective, delving deeply into the diary of a Nazi air ace, records of Rudolf Hess‘s quixotic flight to Scotland, and reports of the clumsy antics of the Luftwaffe’s Hermann Göring. It’s a remarkable accomplishment.

“From the very start,” Larson notes, “Churchill understood a fundamental truth about the war: that he could not win it without the eventual participation of the United States.” Deservedly, then, Larson devotes special attention to Churchill’s relentless campaign to persuade President Franklin Roosevelt to resist the isolationists who hobbled him politically and come to the defense of embattled Britain. This story is well known, but Larson tells it with a light touch, revealing intimate details of the two men’s growing relationship that are often missing from scholarly accounts of the war.
A focus on Churchill’s family and his inner circle

Larson draws our attention squarely to the Prime Minister’s inner circle. These were not primarily the exalted figures who populated the War Cabinet such as Viscount Halifax, Anthony Eden, Clement Attlee, and Neville Chamberlain (at the outset), but the men who interacted with him on a daily basis and often lived with him at Chequers and Ditchley on the weekends. These were Churchill’s friends—the men in whom he confided:

** Press lord Max Aitken, Lord Beaverbrook, an intimate friend whom he pressed into service as Minister of Aircraft Production. It was Beaverbrook who bullied nearly everyone around him regardless of rank to circumvent the many bureaucratic hurdles that had kept aircraft production low. And he was wildly successful, “doubling fighter output within his first three months” on the job.

** General Hastings (Pug) Ismay, his chief military advisor. As Private Secretary Jock Colville noted in his diary, “Churchill owed more, and admitted that he owed more” to him for his aid and support “than to anybody else, military or civilian, in the whole of the war.”

** Frederick (The Prof) Lindemann, Churchill’s personal scientific advisor. The Prof was an eccentric who obsessed about clever but often unworkable ideas that seem to have captivated Churchill. In fact, the Prime Minister’s fascination with gadgets is well known and has been the subject of books, film, and television production.

His wife, Clementine Churchill, played an advisory role from to time but her suggestions were less likely to be heeded. And the Prime Minister happily spent hour after hour with the two men Franklin Roosevelt sent on special missions to confer with him: first, Harry Hopkins, and later Averell Harriman. Both became, for a time, fully fledged members of the inner circle as well.

Many others had front-row seats on the Prime Minister’s day-to-day life

Others, no doubt, considered themselves intimate with Churchill, but if Larson’s account may be believed, Beaverbrook, Ismay, and the Prof were the stalwart and indispensable men to whom Churchill most often turned for support during that first year of his time at 10 Downing Street.

Others with front-row seats convey how these men all interacted, principally private secretary John (Jock) Colville. But Larson’s account is enriched by the passages in Colville’s diary that reflect on his unrequited love for a young woman and on daughter Mary Churchill girlish preoccupations during the early months of the war. And the story of Churchill’s unhappily married daughter-in-law, Pamela Churchill, adds a fascinating dimension to the tale. (First wed to Randolph, Churchill’s spendthrift and philandering son, Pamela later married Hollywood and Broadway producer Leland Hayward, and, finally, in 1979, Averell Harriman, with whom she had had an affair in the course of the events related in The Splendid and the Vile.

The title of this stirring book comes not from Shakespeare or one of the ancients, as we might surmise, but from a passage in one of Jock Colville’s diaries: “Never was there such a contrast of natural splendor and human vileness.”
titles: An intimate view of Churchill during the Blitz, and Larson's best

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
As an American, I really didn't recall school history teachers talking about England prior to the U.S. entering WWII. Rightfully so I suspect because after all it was American History. But then again, World History classes didn't discuss the subject either. Erick Larson however with his very detailed style of writing, did a masterful job of describing the dire consequences England was facing during this period. Winston Churchill had just become Prime Minister and his army was fleeing for their lives at Dunkirk. The only good news was, not as many British Soldiers were killed in this evacuation as predicted. If one may call that good news. Mr. Larson really has the reader feeling how alone England really was in their efforts of defending democracy from the German Empire. Germany's Blitzkrieg rolled over Europeans with great ease and the soon realized vulnerable French, were now the only defense between them and the German army. The French had prepared for the invasion by building a massive line of impenetrable connected bunkers. Who knew the German army would just go around them. Shortly, the French negotiated a surrender with Germany and now there was no protection from being invaded. For the 1st year of Churchill's administration each and every day the British people were unnerved at the prospect of be invaded. The only thought Hitler and his staff didn't consider was resistance. Hitler mistakenly took the entire British Empire as nothing to be concerned about and with his advisors were convinced they could take England with their air bombardment followed up by a ground invasion. What i learned from this book is more about the resolve of the British people. For many days, several in a row, the clouds over England at night were full of bombers applying massive destruction to a historic empire. And yet, people went out to dinner, attended movies, plays and actually danced many nights away at local and regional night clubs. I'm sure there were people that stayed in bunkers, basements or what have you, but for the most part, people seem to treat the bombs as an inconvenience as they went about their work days. I really enjoyed the description by Mr. Larsen of Joseph Goebbels, one of the most powerful leaders of the Nazi party, as he painted his fingernails and dressed up in lavish outfits to attend public parties. There seems to be no denying that Churchill had is idiosyncrasies as well. Mr. Larson described how he enjoyed putting on his uni suit and marching around in front of his dinner guests to military marching tunes until way into the early hours of the following day. There were at times I thought perhaps too much ink was spent on Mary Churchill but then again, it sets the tone for what all British citizens were up to as well. I have read all of Erick Larson's books and as soon as I saw this one offered for a pre purchase via Amazon I clicked the order button with out even reading the bibliography. It's not my favorite Larson book, but by far not my least favorite. Very entertaining and causes one to reflect on some of the similarities we are all facing with this deadly Covid19 Virus.

Treat yourself and buy this book.
titles: The bombing of England in the days leading up to United States entering the war!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I started this book as a skeptic having about everything I could get my hands on that pertains to Winston Churchill and WWII. When is enough a enough. As the chapters unfolded I began to realize that enough was not enough.

Erik Larsen’s detailed Churchill was ahead of anything I had yet read (I’ve read plenty). The book details the seemingly endless horror of the London bombings. How could they endure this brutality with a stiff upper lip goes beyond my imagination.....yet they did.

The insight on the Churchill circle of family and friends adds an unexpected element and alone is a story unto itself.

Bottom line this is a great book and if you’ve read enough on WWII and Churchill until you read this you haven’t.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
England is at war with Germany, Winston Churchill has been elected Prime Minister, and the island is under relentless bombardment by the Luftwaffe. The first year of Churchill’s leadership was a crucial time for a number of reasons. Increasing production of airplanes and war material was certainly critical, but even more important was keeping morale high. Larson repeatedly emphasizes that it was Churchill’s oratorial skills that bolstered the nation. “…Churchill demonstrated a striking trait: his knack for making people feel loftier, stronger, and, above all, more courageous.” Again: “Churchill’s great trick… was his ability to deliver dire news and yet leave his audience feeling encouraged and uplifted.”

Not only is this a detailed look at Churchill’s first year in office, it’s about the people closest to him. His inner circle included family, staff, and various war ministers, and each played a vital role in supporting the formidable PM. I learned quite a bit about how desperately England relied on America’s aide and how the Lend-Lease Act was paramount to England not capitulating to the Nazi onslaught. I was also previously unaware that the British navy actually fired on French ships so they wouldn’t end up in German possession after the fall of France.

As always, Larson delivers a compelling story in an approachable, engaging narrative. The Blitz came alive on the pages and I could feel the desperation and the hope of the civilians who endured the long nights of air raids. As one observer noted, seeing Churchill console bombed Londoners: “…it typified the uniquely unpredictable magic that was Churchill – his ability to transform ‘the despondent misery of disaster into a grimly certain stepping stone to ultimate victory.’”

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
But WInston Churchill had so much more to offer! In Erik Larson's latest history, the reader learns in-depth about the first year of Churchill's role as Prime Minister, May 1940-May 1941. The new PM displayed unbridled optimism and boundless energy. His "Secret Circle" included men of industry, science and politics. Despite 57 nights of consecutive bombing by the Luftwaffe, Churchill's oratory and his presence, often in tears, amidst the rubble of London, forcibly demonstrated his grit, sympathy and empathy. Churchill and Britain would fight on! He knew he could not win without the help of the USA. Larson deftly unfolds the diplomatic game of "cat and mouse" between Churchill and FDR until the agreement for Lend Lease was finalized.

Larson's compelling prose puts the reader in the chambers of Parliamentary debate, in the cockpits of both Messerschmitts and Spitfires, in the London tube during the blitz, in the night fire-bombing of Coventry and at the county estate of Chequers where Churchill "recharged his batteries" and convened with trusted advisors. Here too, the reader glimpses the drama in the lives of the Churchill family including his supportive wife, Clementine, the coming-of-age daughter, Mary and the unraveling of his son Randolph and duaghter-in-law Pamela Digby. Larson keeps the drama high domestically, nationally and internationally. As always with this author, it is history presented at its best!
titles: "I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat."

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Another splendid book from Eric Larson. His works are the result of exhaustive research and his talent at bringing authenticity and life to history. This is a unique book, especially since, as Larson freely admits, there are thousands and thousands of pages written about WW II, Churchill, and every single day of the war. Yet Larson has found original material in Mary Churchill's diary, and integrates it brilliantly in the diaries of Churchill's assistants, Goebbels, and the British observers who wrote about the morale of the country in real time. It's Mary Churchill who really stands out. She tried to be a young girl enjoying life in the midst of hell. Her sweetness and innocence stand out in a time of death, vileness, and horror. Hitler wanted England to quietly surrender but when that didn't happen, and indeed, Churchill and the RAF had the temerity to bomb German cities in 1940 and 1941, the gloves came off and Hermann Goring filled the sky with bombers. He delivered relentless and unopposed waves of air attacks, especially during nights when the moon was full. The targets were allegedly military centers, as at Coventry, but then all of London was being bombed, with thousands dead. Larson makes these days of suffering, courage, and even humor come alive! Highly recommended for anyone who wants to know what a true leader is all about.
titles: "I have nothing to hide." Winston Churchill

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: It doesn't matter that you already may know how Churchill's first year as wartime PM went. Larson has written a superb page-turner, and what a brilliant touch--to being into close focus the lives of Churchill's youngest child, Mary, and that of his personal secretary, Coville, drawing on their diary entries. The narrative is at once epic and intimate in scope. And it so poignantly speaks to our dire present. If it hadn't been for Churchill's unique genius for both telling brutal truths and inspiring/energizing, England would almost certainly have capitulated to Nazi Germany following Poland's fall in 1939. Now, when we most need truth tellers who can buoy us up, who do we have...other than Dr. Faucci?

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I could not put this book down. A fascinating read. Highly recommend.

I have read most of Erik Larson's books, and they are all very, very good. But for some reason I could not put this book down. It's a fascinating look at the period in London form 1940 to 1941 when London, and much of England was mercessly bombed by Hitler and how Churchill lead the Brits at that time. Maybe because we are currently in the middle of the COVID-19 pandemic? How the English handled the horrific death and destruction that happened day after day, week after week for 8 solid months. Amazing history that I did not know that well. It ends when America is attacked at Pearl Harbor.
titles: Excellent book, easily one of his best

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Another outstanding researched and written drama by Erik Larson. Have read all his works and they reside as treasures in my library. When reading “A Note to Readers” about moving to NYC caused the question of “Why” but fortunately the experience resulted in this magnificent book. The comment of “how did the Churchill’s and their circle cope?” can be expanded to the entire British people of the time! As mentioned Churchill caused the WWII British to recognize and employ their own courage when facing alone the might of the NAZI military and its extremist and inhuman ideology. While Churchill felt relief with Imperial Japan’s attack on U.S. Pearl Harbor 7 December 1941 Hitler did not declare war on the U.S. until 11 December 1941. An historic “What if ?” is what would have been the consequences if Hitler had not declared war on the U.S.? What influence would the America First Committee (AFC) and its NAZI sympathizers play in thwarting President Franklin Roosevelt’s efforts to engage Hitler’s Germany? What is also particularly concerning that reading of this period of the NAZI regime in Berlin one hears echoes of the present.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: What got off to a slow start, this book became incredibly hard to put down, like all of Larson's books. The book closely follows his process of brilliantly creating non-fiction books into thrilling, character driven page turners. I have read many books on Churchill, and many, many more on the Battle of Britain and the Blitz. This ranks up there as a new favorite. While making it very clear that Churchill was a deeply flawed man, the book is clearly also a love letter to our amazing Winnie. Brilliant, reactive, warm, cold, funny, infuriating Winnie. The book also focused on wartime production, the home front, the Churchill family and the inner circle. There's a whole lot happening, but it all weaves together into an excellent read. Typical Larson. And I mean that in the best possible way. I love his formula, and I love that he knows his fans love it. I always liken reading his books to watching Ken Burns documentaries. You know what to expect, its warm and familiar, and you would not want it any other way. The only difference I would like to see with this one, is part 2 !

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I’ve read many books about Churchill, some enjoyable and revealing, like Candace Millard’s excellent “Winston Churchill, Hero of Empire”, others scholarly and a bit of a struggle to get through, like Andrew Roberts’ encyclopedic “Churchill, Walking With Destiny”. But, no book I’ve read gave such an intimate look into who Churchill really was. A man of contradictions; grave and determined, yet often childlike in his zest for life, steely eyed and resolved, yet able to cry easily in sorrow or joy, proud, but completely lacking in vanity.
I admit to being a big fan of Eric Larson’s ability to explore a subject or period we may already be familiar with, but somehow make it suspenseful. He’s adept at sprinkling in humorous anecdotes and developing characters who may have been overlooked, and telling the story from many points of view.
This approach is particularly effective here, as the portrait of wartime Churchill, his family and many associates emerges in rich detail.
It’s a fantastic, fun read, very well sourced and elaborately foot noted...even his reimagined conversations are all based on someone who was there.
While I’ve enjoyed every book Larson’s written, I believe this his finest work.
titles: Get to Know Churchill Like You Never Have.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have read, I think, everything Erik has written. I adore his books and his writing style. While he is, as always, a wonderful writer in this book it just went on and on in a not very interesting manner. A bit of it was my fault because when I like an author I tend to purchase their books without really knowing what they're about. I did not realize it was a very specific time in Winston Churchill's life and not the entire war. It was interesting to read how regular life went on during heavy attack and bombing, but 1/2 way thru the book I found myself wanting to speed thru to the later part of the war and see how Churchill defeated the enemy and what his inner circle was thinking then. But as it was just the few years of heavy attach and strife the victorious ending of the war was glossed over in summary. Reading countless pages about what he wore, what was served for breakfast and how long he chewed each portion got a bit tedious. Overall I am sure people will still read this because it wasn't terrible - just not what I was expecting.
titles: I usually love Erik Larson's books but...

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Just got this! So far, this promises to expand our history about WWII.
titles: Churchill 's life was dynamic compared to the persona  of our recent leaders!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I love Erik Larson and his books but this one was disappointing. There was too much recounting of the bombings and I know this was a horror and at the crux of the story but there were so many sorties described you started to glaze over. It does make you wonder how London and England recovered and went on to become the beautiful city and country that they are today. The resilience of the people under Churchill is more than admirable. The interjections of some of the family member's love life wasn't very interesting and didn't more the story forward much even while giving a glimpse into their lives as war swirled around them. We all know how it ended and the steps to victory. Access to diaries and the research involved on the part of Larson is impressive, however. My one major gripe is the lack of photographs (unless my Kindle version didn't add them). I don't know what most of Churchill's entourage looked like and that would have helped place them in context. You can tell so much from a portrait.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This book is hefty enough to be a stalwart companion during a two week quarantine. Larson provides a plethora of little known facts and interesting anecdotes regarding Churchill's first year as Prime Minister. Drawing extensively from diaries of the family, employees and advisors described within, Larson provides a harrowing glimpse of life during the Battle of Britain. The ability of those in England to persist with their quotidian tasks amid the nightly horror should provide some hope to our society's angst. Fires were extinguished, birthdays were celebrated, and people endured. So will we.
titles: An Excellent Choice During a Pandemic

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I was completely engrossed from first pages to the end. I worried at the end as I saw the remaining pages coming to an end.
The place to end the book made sense but I could have easily read another 500 pages. Hard to put down.
I've read several other WWII books. My father fought in Army ETO and I heard stories from my mother about life in US but this book made me feel so much.
Larson is a master at bringing the story together.
I could hear the planes and bombs and had the most vivid picture of the Blitz night as if I were really standing right in the middle of it.
Highly recommend the book. In a period of world events now it makes it more incredible hoe the English stood up to the challenge and showed amazing unity together. Churchill was a man for the time like few others might have been.

Hoping Larson has another book in the works. Now reading In The Garden Of The Beasts by Larson- I can already sense a few chapters in I'll have some late nights reading this week again!
titles: Favorite book I have read in a long time

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Where do I start? This is by far the most fascinating history book I have ever had the pleasure to read. Mr. Larson’s writing style and they way he tells a story really speaks to me. The way he tells the story about Churchill gripped me from the start. I loved how he showed the inner workings of how Churchill lived and operated. This is the third of his books I have read and by far this is the best. I believe that Mr. Larson is one of the greatest authors I have ever had the pleasure of reading. I loved every minute of this book. When I got to the epilogue, I was actually sad that the book was coming to a close. This is the first book I have ever bought the kindle version and half way through it, I ordered the hardcover version. I cannot say enough about this amazing book or this author. If he published a phone book, I’d read it. If you are at all interested in history, specifically WW2 history, read this book. You will not be disappointed.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Erik Larson is a wonderful writer - he seems to do a lot of research, and really knows how to make history come alive (read "Isaac's Storm," "Devil in the White City," "In the Garden of Beasts," etc.).
His latest is an up-close and personal look at Winston Churchill's first year as prime minister, during the early days of World War II. Larson draws from diaries kept by family and staff, and paints a picture of Churchill as a family man, as a leader, and as an individual. Some of the "peripheral" characters really come to life, as well - Winston's daughter, Mary; his personal secretary, Jock Colville (who went on to work for Queen Elizabeth); Churchill's quirky right-hand man, Lord Beaverbrook; and others.
Larson's recounting of the London bombings, and Churchill's response to them, were very affecting.
Churchill was definitely a leader for his time, and Larson's book adds to the large body of material illustrating why.
titles: Engaging, personal look at Churchill's first year as prime minister

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Engrossing, well-constructed day-by-day chronicle of Winston Churchill's first year as Prime Minister as London, facing the perceived imminent threat of invasion, reeled under nightly Nazi bombardment (eerily paralleling the world situation today, again under siege from an unseen invader). The book makes very clear Churchill's amazing strengths in shepherding the nation through that horrendous period, as well as showing his very human side.
My only complaints:
---details about personal and intimate relationships of some of the players, taken from their diaries and/or personal papers, are annoying and irrelevant, and detract from the overall wartime drama;
---the title! Where on earth did Larson come up with such a bad title for this book? (Well, in truth, it's not much better than "In the Garden of the Beasts," so I suggest that next time, the author ask a trusted friend for help!)
titles: Engrossing chronicle of the Battle of Britain, mostly

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
This book gave me a needed perspective on Covid-19. As frustrating as it can be to 'shelter at home' England had it much worse during the time of the Blitz. Then, a German bomb could come down with little warning, destroying people's homes and killing many inhabitants. As a result, many chose to shelter in the subway, sleeping on the platform. Some sent their young children away to the countryside. Certain foods were rationed--meat, sugar, eggs, fruit. Gasoline was rationed as well. Yet people went about their daily lives with courage, for the most part.

This book follows the first year of WWII in Europe, especially as it impacted the British government led by Winston Churchill. Flawed as he was in many ways, he led the people with foresight and grace. Quite a contrast with our own current administration.
titles: In the time of Covid-19, this gives some needed perspective.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I loved this book. Larson has achieved a pinnacle of his career in how deftly he wove the story of Churchill’s first year as Prime Minister, along with the story through diaries of his daughter and a few others closest to him. (I’m reading Larson’s The Devil in the White City now and it’s not done so well as this). Wow! To take non-fiction and turn it into a thrill ride. How masterful. It’s turned me into a Churchill junkie. I want more, but I want it written as well as this is. Read it! You won’t be sorry!
titles: Read this! It’s so well done! Masterful.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
“The Splendid and the Vile” is an amazing deep-dive into Winston Churchill’s first years as Prime Minister, as Britain entered war with Germany. Though World War II Literature is vast, and the history well known, Larsen’s book is a unique and captivating story, as told chronologically (nearly daily), of the life of Churchill during Britain’s darkest days. Churchill’s strength, courage, confidence, and eccentric humanity is recounted in detail by official documents, and the writings of his closest friends and family. To say I loved this book is an understatement.

I read and listened to “The Splendid and the Vile,” alternating with Audible and Kindle. Though I generally prefer reading the story, listening was a superior experience, and found myself listening to passages after having read the text.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I am a huge fan of Winston Churchill and have read numerous book both written by and about him. I consider him to be one of the seminal figures of the 20th century. I have also read several books written by Eric Larson, enjoying them all and finding them quite educational. Thus, this book was a natural for me.

The book is a highly detailed look at the first year of Churchill’s Ministry, focusing on the London Blitz and Battle of Britain. When I say “highly detailed”, what I mean is meticulously and painstakingly detailed. Much of what is covered is so mundane and repetitive as to be off-putting. Nevertheless, there are some enlightening and highly interesting nuggets, but fighting through the chaff to get to the wheat can become tiresome at times, hence the middle of the road rating.
titles: Must Fight Through the Chaff to Get to the Wheat.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have read many books on Winston Churchill and the first year of the Second World War. This is easily in the top tier. Partly, that is an effect of the author's very obvious skills and careful scholarship. Partly, it is a consequence of taking earth shaking events that seem to dwarf all of us and examining them from a very different perspective from that to which we are all accustomed. Vignettes drawn from Churchill and, most importantly, from members of his immediate family seldom encountered outside of footnotes bring the drama of the Battle of Britain to vivid life. The careful reader will find fascinating insights into the UK class system as well as the motivations, as revealed through primary sources like diaries, of the participants in events. I recommend this book without reservation!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
This is an enjoyable book and gives us a behind the scenes look at Churchill during his, and England's, finest hour. Larson keeps a tight focus on the Churchill family throughout the book.

I have to say I do not count this as among the best books Larson has written. I don't think it is a the level of In the Garden of Beats, or the Devil in the White City. The events are so well known that we always know the outcome.

A better treatment of the same time frame is featured in The Duel by John Lukacs which focuses on the comings and goings of Churchill and Hitler during the Battle of Britain.

But Larson is such a talent as a story teller that the book goes by quickly. A little over 100 separate chapters in a book that comes in just under 500 pages.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Brilliant. Awesome. Extraordinary!!
Inside the Battle of Britain on the first line as a true witness of events unfolding as you read this book. CHURCHILL displays his extraordinary leadership abilities and oratory skills to keep the people spirits high amid a thunderstorm of german bombs, and to save his government from falling as setback after setback occur in the theater of war. A different portray of the battle of Britain as the RAF wins the daylight fighting, forcing the Luftwaffe to switch to night bombing, , starting a nightmare for CHURCHILL and the British people. This is a story about real people who look like extraordinary characters of a fiction book telling us a surreal story. A real inspiring story that any people loving of freedom should know.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have to get better at reading all of the titles! I didn't realize that the book was just about the Blitz until nearly the end and I was like, what, is this it? That aside, I'm not one for reading about science and technology - of which there is a fair amount in this book - but, it these discussions were flavored with enough personal stories to give them some interest. I can't say that I was overwhelmed with how great it was, but it generally kept my interest and I did learn a lot. I was a little perplexed as to why Larson followed Mary Churchill. It was a little disappointing. There was enough information about her to interest me, but not enough to really tell me what happened with her. If you're going to tell me about her romance, give me a little more info!
titles: A good study of some of England's response to the Blitz

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Mr. Larson does it again with this superbly researched treatment of Winston Churchill's leadership during the London Blitz. After France surrenderedl shockingly quickly to the Nazis, the burden of stopping Germany's onslaught fell on Britain. America's isolationism and Roosevelt's reluctance to rock the cart in an election year made Britain's situation very difficult. This book highlights the incredible courage and determination of the nation and its prime minister while waiting for the US to officially join the war effort. Britain had not been invaded since the 1066 Norman conquest and Churchill was not going to let it happen on his watch. Fans of WWII history will especially appreciate the "behind the scenes" look at Churchill and his circle.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have been fascinated with Churchill all my adult life. Also, I have enjoyed other Larson books. I saw that this book had just become available soon after we were quarantined because of Covid 19. It seemed like the right time to get the kindle version which I did. It is so appropriate to the time we are living. I was enthralled with the way Larson told the story of Churchill and the blitz. I thought I knew the story but reading this book made it even more real and clear just how much suffering the British peop!e endured, how they stayed strong and United through it all and how much Churchill clearly influenced the resolve of the people. He was the man destined to lead them at that time. I highly recommend this book and have told many people about it.
titles: Book for the time we are currently living

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have read dozens of books and seen many movies that cover the subject of WW2 and Winston Churchill. What could Mr. Larson (or anyone for that matter), write that has not already been written? Well the short answer is: a hell of a lot. Mr. Larson sifts through an ocean of documented history and produced one of the most intimate portraits of Winston Churchill I have ever read. What made the books so compelling to me was the opinions of those in Churchill's inner circle. Opinions written in diaries they were not suppose to have kept (as a matter or national security.) These are not musings after the fact but real time opinions while the bombs were still falling. Thank you Mr. Larson for shedding new light on an old subject.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This rating has nothing to do with the book. I bought this for my Kindle. It stopped working at 7% and I finally got it to move forward. At 25%, it shut down completely and will not move forward. I'd love to read the remainder. But how do I do that? And, how do I get my money back?
titles: This won't work on my Kindle

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: The first book by the author that I read was Isacc’s Storm. I knew a little about the hurricane that hit Galveston in early 20 th century. He made the characters jump from the page, and made a story about extreme weather very interesting. This book also has the same technique, using journals and diaries, and I begin to feel as though I were in London in 1940. I have recommended this book to my husband who enjoys World War II history, even though I have not yet finished the book. Several reviews mention that the book reads like a novel, although we know the cast of characters lived and breathed. It is a big book but I am anxious to read more and learn even more about the period.
titles: Fascinating insight to history about beginning of World War II

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have read all of Erik Larson's books and found this one to another excellent read. As an historian, I really appreciate the way Mr. Larson can teach us about historical events while making it both fascinating and interesting. Over the years, I studied Churchill's life and times. This book, however provides a refreshing look at a giant of the 20th Century. Churchill's extended family is examined in some detail. That he had to deal with "problem children" while trying to hold Great Britain a free nation was quite an ordeal. It is gratifying to know that there have been great leaders in the past and that we will surely have them at some point again in the future.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Fair warning: I am a huge fan of Erik Larson and have read all of his books multiple times. I'm a lover of history, but I love it even more when it's told to me as a good story. Eric Larson never forgets to tell me a good story. It is a rare talent that one doesn't see in the typical history teacher.
As always, the book is meticulously researched and provides intimate detail to draw the reader in to the lives of the famous but usually remote characters. Even more amazing, I felt like I was in the London Blitz; as though I was personally experiencing it on a day-to-day basis. The only bad thing about this book is that finishing it means a long wait for the next new book.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This the forth book I've read of Mr. Larson's and I've enjoyed them all. I listened to The Garden of Beasts and didn't care for it that much. Eric makes history come alive. I really like the way he name drops like bringing Edward R. Murrow and Ian Fleming into the story. I had just finished reading books on Pearl Harbor and I am fully convinced that the attack on Pearl Harbor was no surprise to FDR. He was only surprised about the strength of Japan. He did need the attack in order to change the will of the country and congress. This book helps demostrate the pressure he was under to enter the war. This book also helps one know Churchill a little better.
titles: Takes history from Black and White to HD

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: this was a tedious read.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: You Need to play attention to the actual title of this book because while it deals with Churchill, his entourage and World War II, much of the book also centers on the love life of his daughter, her dinner parties and the relationship between Churchill's son and that son's wife. These parts of the book are tedious, too long and really not relevant to Churchill's servce as Prime Minister. Plus these references are placed in potions of chapters which chapters have nothing to do with those characters. Perhaps the author just wished to build his rereference material. This material made the book to boring in part and resulted in me skim reading those portons as I went deeper into the read. Had I known so much of the book dealt with this extraneous material I would not have bought the book.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I've read thousands of pages about Winston Churchill and WWII including William Manchester's excellent three volume biography on The Lion. Yet, this new book brought novel stories and more delightful tales about the hero of Great Britain and perhaps the Western World. I am a big fan of Larson and highly recommend several of his books - my favorite about the crossing of the Lusitania. This did not disappoint. His description of the nightly bombings of London and other English towns were terrifying and new to me. He also used family diaries to provide insights into Clementine (wife), the children and their spouses. Randolf, his son, is a fascinating loser. Very well documented and well written. Don't miss it.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: World War II may be the most analyzed and written about conflict in history. It seems new tales of horror or valor keep getting unearthed. Here, though, Erik Larson focuses on one of its most prominent figures, Winston Churchill. The book is set squarely on his first year as Prime Minister and he is surrounded by a rich and fascinating cast of characters. The book nicely balances the doings in England with parallel activity in Germany, and occasionally America, so it feels rounded. Larson's lucid writing keeps the narrative from getting cumbersome. A very good read and a reminder of the sacrifices the common folk made without giving up hope.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I cannot say enough good about this book. Incisive, well-told, story of Churchill’s first year and a half in office. Masterfully woven tale amounting to a true insider’s view of the man who saved western democracy and freedom as we know it today. Highly readable and laced with delightful morsels that keep the reader “seated at Churchill’s table” dining with the great man over a sumptuous feast and yet ever begging for more. Obviously most highly recommended.
titles: Fabulous Read - An inside view of the greatest leader of the last 100 years!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Another very informative historical novel by Erik Larson! What comes to mind immediately is the stark contrast between Churchill's bold leadership in his first year as PM and the deflection, half-truths, conspiracy theories, and outright lies that emanate from the present administration in Washington. Our nation will hopefully elect a president with some Churchillian qualities in November.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have always been intrigued by Churchill, ever since I went to a Churchill museum in London. He is a fascinating character,who had an extraordinary love of his country and it's inhabitants I am not a history nut but I did learn things that I did not know about the war. I would recommend this definitely to a person who loves history. I think most of us would love to have Churchill' s energy and have his optimism for any battle that we face in life.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
There are many Churchill books from a battle, date or event perspective. This account seemed to have a more personal perspective. It gave a nice context to the man and his surrounding people. It was the first I've read the fleshed out the influence of his wife and family.
I've read most of Larsons books and enjoy his storytelling. A very readable, and unique Churchill perspective.
titles: Great Churchill book from a personal perspective

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: If I did not know my history, I would say that Erik Larson has written a fascinating book of fiction. But as we follow Winston Churchill from the day he took office through the Battle of Britain we are introduced to the complexities of the man and the situation he faced. Adolf Hitler invaded Belgium and Holland on his first day as prime minister. It didn’t get any easier from there as 45,00 British would die during Hitler’s campaign. We read how Churchill pleaded the United States for support. I could feel the dark days of the nation through Larson’s narrative. I’ve read many books on Churchill in the past, this is one of the very best.
titles: A Wonderfully Told Story Of Churchill's Challenges

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Readers will find exactly 'a saga of Churchill and his leadership style, his family and key supporters' actions; and British defiance throughout the Blitz. This is not a 'fast read' but interesting insights pop up regularly. The writing conveys how wearing those days of uncertainty were to live through and to work through. 'Names', like press baron Lord Beaverbrook, Pamela Churchill (soon to become wife to Averell Harriman, Clementine Churchill and so on regularly recur. Worth buying; worth reading. The same Uncertainty and Change found in Wartime Britain is much like that found in dealing with Pestillence these days.
titles: Diaries and Research Provide Insider Insights

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Larson has lived up to his other stories as he tells this one from a perspective different from most biographies but at the same time a true documentation of the man and the timeframe in which Larson tells the story. Larson had guts to write a story about the man so much as been written about.
I couldn’t help but compare the crisis of the war Churchill waged with the current time in which I read this book. A silent pandemic has placed the world on hold much as WWII did. Just the glimpse of how Britains dealt with the panic of bombs falling constantly on their beloved city for months on end gave me hope that will leadership and courage the world can come out of this medical pandemic better on the other side.
titles: Very thoughtful story of one of the heroes of the 20th Century

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I must admit I thought a book about WWII to be boring and I thought Churchill was just this leader of England who rallied the people to stave off the Germans. I didn't realized what occurred that first year of WWII for Britian and its people. Eric Larson has a way to bring the reader into the past as though you are living it in real time. The book is rather long but I just flew through the pages totally entranced. The only thing I wanted was pictures that usually accompany his books. I read actual paper books and having this feature would have made the experience better. Of course I could go on the internet.
titles: Fulfills Eric Larson's ability to write

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: An Interesting recounting of life In London During World War II. Most of the action occurs during the blitz which began at approximately the same time as Winston Churchill became the Prime Minister. The primary sources are the diaries of John Colville and Mary Churchhill along with numerous others. The story in London is interspersed with chapters filling us in on what is going on with Hitler and his primary associates. The book ends with the entry of United States into the war at the end of 1942. Larson provides numerous insights to the day to day life of Churchhill and his family.
titles: Churchill and his family and associates during the First year of his becoming Prime Minister

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I generally love Erik Larson‘s books, but this is a story that has been told so many times, and now again by somebody I expect more from. Erik Larson usually tells a story that I am at least somewhat unfamiliar with. Halfway through I felt I had read enough. While always an interesting history to hear there isn’t much new to expand on. Sadly Erik Larson proves that here.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Descends into TMZ gossip world about Churchill preferences for certain kinds of underwear, bath time rituals...really? Didn’t need to know. Seemed Less humanizing than an attempt to humiliate the memory of a great hero. Interesting that the British government encouraged its citizens to keep diaries during WWII, and that they are available in the British archives, where Larson accessed them as fodder for this book. Decent read, too much sloppy TMZ stuff for me. Read “In the Garden...”, “Luisitania “, and/or “...White City” if you haven’t. They are his better books.
titles: Loved previous books, this is too TMZ for me

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
If George Washington was the navigational beacon to the American Revolution, Winston Churchill was the inspiration and heart to England's defense against the German aerial assault of the Battle of Britain (1940-1941).

I have read several of Mr. Larson's books and I have enjoyed every one. Mr. Larson has the talent through his style of writing to strip layer after layer of his major characters so that the reader develops a personalized relationship with each one. As a result, a sense of familiarity is created between the reader and character. The reader is transcended into the scene where one is not an onlooker but is directly connected to that scene be it in a war room, a dinner party or in a Nazi bomber plane. This formula makes for a wonderful reading experience.

Mr. Larson's writing style leaves me with a "what is going to happen next" moment. His ability to weave his central theme in a good guy/bad guy interplay makes his books riveting to read. Such is the style found in THE SPLENDID AND THE VILE.

In reading this book, I have developed a new found respect for Winston Churchill. His courage that he displayed through the endless Nazi bombing raids on English cities is remarkable. His encouragement to those around him and to the English people to carry on, his perseverance, his exuberance, his love for his country are all factors to England's survival during WW II. He carried the United Kingdom forward through its darkest hour.

Winston Churchill represented a true statesman so sorely missed on today's international stage of diplomacy.

In 1968 Americans were singing, "Where are you Joe DiMaggio, your nation turns its lonely eyes on you." In 1940, England turned its eyes on Winston Churchill.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Well written. But terribly made. Poor paper, very ill bound, torn in the back pages from the binding. Really not readable. Get the kindle version. I’m really shocked that Larson would allow the publisher to put this out.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: As always from Larson, another great book.Churchill and the blitz,will give you a very good idea of exactly how bad it was for Londoners at that time. My father was a warden and told me many tales that i identify with Larson's text very well. The German side is explained in depth,i especially liked the story of Hess landing in Scotland.Larson gives the reader another slant on Churchill which will be appreciated by anybody who has read of him before,this is a little different and an eye opener to his private life and family.A very good read.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Taking nothing away from his other well researched and written books, this one is the triple cream of the crop. Of course, the ingredients could hardly be better. Churchill leaps from the pages in all his grand, grandiose, flawed and brilliant glory as he defends Britain against Nazi Germany during the first years of the WWII. The story follows the Churchill family, it's friends and staff as they navigate the emotional storms, the eccentricities, and the physical exhaustion. Oh, just get the book and forget this review.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Mr Larson is a favorite author of mine. This book about Churchill, his family, his political team, and maybe the most difficult time ever for the United Kingdom does not disappoint. Churchill was a great leader when you needed one. I marveled at the personal and social habits explored in the book for Churchill and his cohorts. The book also painted the personalities of the top Nazi leaders. What a story from 1939 to 1941; and it expanded my knowledge of the day to day efforts and disappointments of the group. Great Book.
titles: Battle of Britain-  Churchill 's perseverance and surrounding cast with an almost impossible task

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I consider Larson to be one of the foremost practitioners of the art of historic storytelling. Rather than an all encompassing biography in this book he concentrates on a period and tells stories around the people and events of the time. Rather than try to make it all encompassing he puts a spotlight on the personal lives and peculiarities of individuals who, in other biographies, would have been omitted. This gave it the feeling of a novel than your typical biography. I found it totally engrossing and delightful.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Loved the book up through third chapter. Can't get anything after that except blank page. Tried all the suggestions offered in Kindle help - nothing worked. PLEASE HELP!!!!!!!!!!!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I'm convinced that Erik Larson could write a fascinating book about paint peeling.

When Larson does a book on one of my personal heroes, Winston Churchill, my attention never wavered. The fact that, while Churchill was the character around whom the story revolved, it covered his family and friends as well.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Larson does a masterful job of giving us the full story of Churchill, his family, and all that went on during one of the most difficult times in world history. One gets a real sense of how close the Nazis came to bringing England to surrender, and how important Churchill was during this time. The "back story" of his family and his aides is fascinating, all set against the backdrop of horrific destruction brought night after night by German bombers. An incredible read that I just could not put down.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: It was refreshing to read about a period of time that provides a whole new perspective on a subject that has been covered over and over. Larson is an author I will follow no matter the topic and his effort here is one of his best. It was so interesting to read of a new cast of characters in depth in addition to those we have become so familiar in other renditions. Highly recommend to those familiar with Churchills life and rime and those just dipping their toes into this important time in history.
titles: A splendid effort covering new topics.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I'm an Erik Larson fan since Devil in the White City. His gift is to report detailed historical facts that read like a well paced novel. The greatest part of The Splendid and the Vile is the intricate detail. For two years, Churchill carried the burden of Hitler's imperialism on his shoulders. The insights from the diaries and accounts of family and associates fill in the sketch of this time period leading up to the American entry into World War II with incredible precision and amazing detail. Larson gives us a thoroughly engaging and detailed tapestry on this most impressive text.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I love Larson books. I have read them all, and repeated. I depend on Larson to tell a great story. But this one just didn't engage me. Most Larson books feature a couple story lines and tie them together. This one to involve some story of Churchills daughter (and a few other characters) that didn't capture my interest or didn't seem to have resolution. There were some interesting anecdotes but kept losing interest. I did finish the book and even read the notes and such but without enthusiasm.
titles: Read all of Larson's books but...

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I thought Devil in the White City was great. In the Garden of the Beasts was good. Splendid and the Vile is mostly a bore. Just not very interesting or exciting. Some interesting tidbits here and there but otherwise a chore to get thru.

But what really has me annoyed are all the 5 star reviews that read like 2 or 3 star reviews. Or reviewers who literally haven't read it yet, but they know its going to be 'awesome.' Its a a defensive posture against all those who may smear their author and his/her writing. And that's not right or good because Larson's work has guaranteed 4.5 star status because all these lemmings can't think for themselves--or are bots.

Larson certainly isn't the only author bestowed with critical immunity. Robin Hobb was lauded with praise from GRRM and she's never looked back. Based upon his reference and amazon reviews I read 2 of her books, and IMO they are weak--especially compared to Martin's masterpiece (finish the damn books George!).
