product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This book is absolutely incredible as are ALL of Erik Larson’s books. I’m only 1/2 way through but want to encourage any and all who enjoy reading about history to get started on this masterpiece. It’s beautifully written, concise, insightful; what a staggering amount of thorough research he conducted. Although it’s (obviously) about a different time in history, it’s incredible how timely it feels to be reading. I never knew much about Churchill; but to read (quotes directly from his and his close companions’ diaries) how carefully he and his experts considered and agonized over decisions is fascinating. The high level of expectation that Churchill had for himself and all those around him is astounding. Are there world leaders like this anywhere today? I’m finding this book spellbinding; I’m learning so much and seeing world events in a new, more informed light. Highly recommend.
titles: Fantastic read; especially during these trying times.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: What a joy it was to read The Splendid and The Vile by Erik Larson. The author of The Devil in the White City and In the Garden of Beasts (my favorite book in the last 10 years), vividly describes Churchill, Hitler, and the London Blitz. Although a tad long and occasionally over-detailed, Larson's rare sin is a little too much of a very good thing: extremely well-researched historical facts and excerpts from documents, speeches, memoirs, and unpublished letters and diaries woven exquisitely into a story-telling tapestry that reads like spy fiction. His descriptions of Churchill and his circles of advisors and family members is fascinating, as are the corresponding specifics on Goebbels, Goering, Hess, and -- here and there -- Hitler. In between, we learn plenty about the regular folks in London and how they survived the Battle of Britain: with chins up, spirits high, and soothed constantly by tea. Highly recommended.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Reasons why I loved this book:
1. The sheer amount of detail that went into researching and portraying 1940-1941 in the lives of the Churchills. I felt like I was getting insights into the life of a man and position that I never thought I would understand. Reading this book, the reader is guaranteed to feel ‘amazed’ at the amount of work that must have gone into writing this book.

2. The story is told incredibly well. Covering hundreds of events in that year was no easy task - but you never feel lost or confused at what is “going on”

3. I felt like I was able to see the war from a new perspective of Herman Goerring and Hitler as a tactical means to their growing empire - rather than the often emotional and “evil” nature often depicted in WW2 stories and films. (Not that their actions were any less evil because of this new perspective).

The author has a few semantics that become repetitive throughout the book, especially at the end of the chapters that I wish were not so frequent. It hardly detracted from the quality of the story. I highly recommend reading this book for those interested in learning more about events of WW2.
titles: An impressive and engaging read full of meaningful detail

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Erik Larson has done it again. No wonder it takes him so long to write books, perfection just takes time. I learned so much about Great Britain and World War II and the struggles they had as a nation and as citizens during a horrific time. The book was well written, well thought out It carefully explores the life and times of Churchill and his contemporaries as they struggled desperately to save the nation and the peoples that they loved during this most horrific period of history. Filled with both personal anecdotes and history, Erik Larson has, once again, kept me on the edge of my seat. I highly recommend this book to all who would learn from our past in order to protect our future. Thank you to NetGalley for the opportunity to experience this great book.
titles: An amazing addition to WWII literature.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Whether you know a lot or a little about Winston Churchill, you’re likely to enjoy Erik Larson’s book titled, The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz, an account of the prime minister’s first year in that role beginning in May 1940, a time of great peril. Larson presents the intensity of that time with skill. We can almost feel the German bombs falling on England. Lord Beaverbrook, Professor Lindemann and many others deliver for Churchill and country. Larson captures Churchill’s persistence in the face of opposition at home and from the enemy. Churchill’s mastery of American relations with Roosevelt, Hopkins, and Harriman come to life thanks to Larson’s lively writing. Readers who enjoy well written history for general audiences are those most likely to enjoy this book.

Rating: Four-star (I like it)

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I can't help but view “The Splendid and the Vile” through my own lens, the American daughter-in-law of an English child who was evacuated to Devon during the Blitz. Bestselling author Erik Larson weaves a gripping tale of Winston Churchill, the newly elected British Prime Minister, and those in his orbit during Germany’s bombing of the U.K. in World War II. With his distinctive style, Larson brings many people back to life, often relying on their own accounts, which gives us a personal glimpse into this moment of history.

Although Larson’s storytelling is tremendously entertaining, we can't forget the horror of the devastation, 44,652 civilian deaths, and even more people injured, during the fateful days of 1940 and 1941, as the writer pointed out. Larson’s account of the bombing of Coventry is a moment when it all becomes real, a shift in tone from anecdotes about Churchill, his staff and family, and cunning Nazis with devious strategies. By no means does Larson gloss over the awfulness, but the irony is always that engaging books are written about ghastly times, about endless wars that our species won’t forsake. But these stories must be retold, and we are forever grateful to storytellers like Larson. (Although I read a giveaway edition, I am a big fan of Erik Larson and would have read it anyway.)

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
historical-places-events, historical-research, history, nonfiction, Great Britain

I wouldn't normally read a book about Churchill because of his causing the Anzac massacre at Gallipoli, but this author is known for meticulous research and crediting. This intense scrutiny of the man, his aides and allies, family, and the people of Great Britain during a time for the space of a year when they were under fire in every sense of the word. Hitler and his minions were going about their murderous business, France fell, and the Americans had their heads in the sand. This book humanizes not only Churchill but those around him as well. I was surprised to find myself reading on for long periods of time. It's that well written.
I requested and received a free ebook copy from Crown Publishing via NetGalley. Thank you!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
This is the captivating tale of how Winston Churchill, London and all of England survived the first year of World War II and the relentless bombing raids Hitler and the Nazis inflicted in order to break their spirit. Larsen uses quotes from diaries and letters to elevate the story above the facts and figures and dates and make it personal, populated with well-rounded personalities acting and reacting to events impossible to comprehend. He even almost succeeds at making Churchill himself into someone anyone can identify with. Yet the apparent reality of Churchill defies the attempt and he remains larger-than-life. This is a must-read for anyone interested in this period of history.

Disclosure: Thank you to Netgalley and Crown Publishing for providing a free copy of this book in return for my honest review.
titles: Captivating tale of the Blitz and Winston Churchill's first year as PM

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I rarely read nonfiction, but the exception I try to make is to read Erik Larson's work, so I was excited when I received an ARC of his newest work. The story centers on the first year of Winston Churchill's tenure as Prime Minister. I started the book with good intentions, but unfortunately, the topic did not pull me in enough to complete the book. However, for those who enjoy historical writings about World War II, you should add this book to your must-read list. Thanks to NetGalley for providing an ARC.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I listened to the audio version of this book and loved the close look at Churchill’s circumstances and behavior during the Blitz. However I found the narrator to be a significant drawback and distraction. He mostly uses an oddly staccato pronunciation and strange accent, swallowing the ends of words so they become hard to understand. And his vocalization of women’s speech is also peculiar; he makes them sound simpering and breathy. It reminds of the way adolescent boys sometimes imitate their mothers, minus the falsetto. I wish I had bought a Kindle or print edition of the book instead.
titles: Great book, but try out the narrator before buying the audio version.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I am not a "Churchill scholar," but i read a lot about ordinary people doing extraordinary things during the World Wars and trying to understand their emotional, psychological and physical responses. This was a wonderful book to give a little bit of a glimpse into that first year of WWII from the standpoint of England, its people and its leader - Churchill.
Although you obviously knew where and how all this was going to end, the book nevertheless reads like a novel of intrigue and suspense; you keep turning the pages and carefully following each character. Well written and highly enjoyable.

Certainly an interesting read about England's leader during tumultuous times as a stark contrast to our own current experiences during the challenging times of covid19 and the racial tensions.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: For the bulk of the book, I was enthralled by Larson's account of Churchill's first year as Prime Minister, as England spins further and further into war, and suffers the incredible onslaught of the German air force. His mixing of the mundane, dare one say profane, day-to-day activities and behavior of the PM, family, and associates, with the dramatic events of that time is truly masterful. Why I didn't give this the full 5 stars is that I got the impression that the author either ran out of steam or lost interest as the period portrayed comes to a close, finally finishing with sketch-like remarks on what subsequently happened to many of the players. Somehow that left me with a less than satisfactory conclusion. That being said, the book does leave me wanting to read more of his works.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have read so much about Winston Churchill, it is very hard to surprise me. This book is well researched and well written by Erik Larsen, who also wrote "Devil in the white city" and many others. He is very talented. This new book to some extent is based on diaries of people surrounding Churchill in 1940-41. There are many interesting characters, different personalities reflecting the British character under tremendous pressure. They are truly remarkable people. This audible book also benefits from absolutely outstanding reading by John Lee. There are some books that are really well written, but it takes a real master to advance it to such heights. You actually feel that you are there watching them. He imitates Churchill so well, it warms up my heart. I love this book.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Erik Larson makes history come alive and I have enjoyed every book he has written. This is no exception. This time he focuses on Winston Churchill and his first year as Prime Minister, 1940-1941. The Battle of Britain is a pivotal time for Britain and fears that Germany will overtake them as they have taken Europe are very real. Churchill is the one to lead them through these dark days. "Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few" August 20, 1940.
Using diaries and newly unclassified sources, that year comes to life. The lives of Churchill, his family and those in his inner circle show us how each faced the crisis and I came away with a whole new perspective of Churchill and what he and Britain went through. This is a must read.
titles: Erik Larson has penned another winner

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: What is splendid? Churchill. What is vile? Perhaps Goering most of all, with the exception of Hitler himself of course. And what is most splendid? The magnificent courage and optimism of the British, inspired by Churchill. It's a thrill to hear of these times in surreal detail - tiny little details increase the verisimilitude, almost as if the reader is actually present at the events being described. This is due to the points of view of such people as Mary Churchill, whose diary is often quoted. No detail is unimportant. Splendidly researched, splendidly written - this is a wonderful treat for us now so we too can be inspired by optimism and courage in another era fraught with a different kind of danger.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Read what the great Andrew Roberts, Churchill's finest biographer, said about the book in Air Mail!

Blood, Toil, Tears, and Churchill
BY ANDREW ROBERTS
READING TIME: 5 MINUTES

The popular historian Erik Larson has done it again. The hugely best-selling author of Dead Wake: The Last Crossing of the Lusitania; In the Garden of Beasts: Love, Terror, and an American Family in Hitler’s Berlin; and Isaac’s Storm: A Man, a Time, and the Deadliest Hurricane in History has once more captured an iconic historical moment and brought it vividly to life in near-novelistic prose, yet without inventing a single thing. Dry-as-dust historians, often in the Academy, have a great deal to learn from writers such as Larson, who are introducing the public to the splendor and terror of the past in vast numbers without compromising one iota on fact.
The Splendid and the Vile is the story of the London Blitz, starting from the moment that Winston Churchill became prime minister on May 10, 1940, until the Luftwaffe raid that destroyed the parts of the House of Commons exactly one year later, coincidentally on the same night that Rudolf Hess flew to Scotland.

A Year in the Life

Although Churchill’s family were all brave, this is no hagiography. We are told that Churchill’s son, Randolph, missed the birth of his son by his wife, Pamela, for example, because he was “in bed with the wife of an Austrian tenor, whose monocled image appeared on cigarette trading cards.” Pamela, understandably, was soon sleeping with Franklin Roosevelt’s tall, rich, and impossibly handsome envoy, Averell Harriman, about whom a female reporter told his daughter Kathleen, “For g. sake tell your father next time I have to cover his conference to wear a gas mask so’s I can concentrate on what he’s saying."
Larson makes excellent use of the diary of Mary Soames, Churchill’s delightful (and morally pure) daughter, which resides at the Churchill Archives Centre at Cambridge University, meaning there is new information in this book. His work in the British National Archives has been acute and painstaking, too, and despite writing books on World War II for 30 years I learned a good deal, for instance that only four percent of Londoners used the subways as air-raid shelters, and that cooperative German P.O.W.’s were taken around the Blitzed areas to see how high British morale still was. “Prisoners saw for themselves that London was not lying in ruins as they had been led to believe,” stated one intelligence report, and the process made the P.O.W.’s more cooperative. In late 1942, a captured Luftwaffe officer told interrogators that if German intelligence reports were accurate, the R.A.F. and Allied Forces must by now have “minus 500 aircraft.”
Larson does fine work in countering many revisionist myths about Churchill, such as the libel that he knew about the raid on Coventry in November 1940 but deliberately did nothing to warn the city in order to protect the Ultra decrypting operation, and he similarly dismisses the various conspiracy theories about the Hess flight. For however zippy is Mr. Larson’s prose—there are 101 chapters in 608 pages—facts are sacrosanct to him.
Nor does this book shy away from the vile side of the Blitz: the looting and the thieving; the occasional, but thankfully isolated, outbreaks of people’s depression and defeatism; the extremely basic lavatory facilities in the subway bomb shelters; and so on. He also focuses on the vile Joseph Goebbels and Hermann Göring, and the parts they hoped to play in London’s destruction. Goebbels sent out radio messages intended to make people fear there was a large Fascist fifth column helping the Luftwaffe, for example, hoping that Londoners hunched around their radios would suspiciously ask one another, “Why did that news reader just say porridge for the sixth time?”
There are plenty of humorous moments in this book, too. In September 1940, King George VI and his private secretary, Alec Hardinge, were almost killed in the bombing of Buckingham Palace. “The whole thing happened in a matter of seconds,” the King wrote of the bomb blast in the quadrangle only a few yards away. “We all wondered why we weren’t dead.” Yet the police constable guarding the palace viewed it remarkably objectively, telling the Queen that it had been “a magnificent piece of bombing.”

His Finest Hours

The personality that looms over the whole book is that of Churchill himself, who was taking life-or-death decisions on virtually a daily basis. Early on he was forced to decide whether to evacuate the British Expeditionary Force from Dunkirk, and whether to send the R.A.F. across the Channel for the Battle of France, then raging, or retain it at home for the far more important Battle of Britain to come. Later on he faced equally tough choices about how to counter the daily-expected invasion. What emerges powerfully is that with him in charge, London would have been defended street by street, house by house, brick by brick. As Churchill said, the capital could have “swallowed” an entire German army, just as Stalingrad later did.

As I read this book, I kept wondering what the swelling of powerful emotion was that I felt, sometimes in an almost physical sense. (I’m a naturally undemonstrative Englishman, rarely moved by words on a printed page.) Then I realized that, as a Londoner, it was a feeling of overwhelming pride in my poor, brave, battered old city, which stood up to the very worst that Hitler could throw at it for months on end, while still somehow keeping its dignity, cheerfulness, and iron resolve not to surrender.

I’m a naturally undemonstrative Englishman, yet I had a feeling of overwhelming pride in my poor, brave, battered old city.
The Russians invented the excellent idea of dubbing as “hero cities” some of their metropolises, such as Leningrad and Stalingrad, that fought the Germans to the knife in World War II. Paris retained its beauty by deciding not to go down that route in 1940, but instead declared itself an “open city” to the Germans, and so retained the historical architecture and boulevards that we love today in the City of Light.

Larson expertly describes how, by total contrast, the Heinkel and Dornier bombers flattened whole districts of London, night after terrifying night for months on end, killing tens of thousands of Britons. So London lost much of its ancient built heritage, and there are still ugly scars and gouges on some of our public buildings from that terrible time. For all that Paris is far more gorgeous and elegant, I prefer my hero city.

Andrew Roberts is the author of Churchill: Walking with Destiny
titles: A Fantastic Read. But don't take my word for it

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
ust finished an advanced reader copy of Erik Larson's latest work. Thanks to NetGalley for the copy!

I have read all of Erik Larson's previous works so I am clearly biased. He is such as wonderful writer and storyteller. His books are a complete pleasure to read. His latest is no exception to that rule! I am sucker for all Churchill stories to begin with.

I can't imagine that anyone even a. new reader of Larson's work would be anything but delighted with this one. I learned so much from this story. New sources and Erik Larson's touch make this one a must read for any WWII student.

This will be a real hit with his current fans and will win many new ones I'm certain. You will see what it was like to live in Britain at the start of the war. You will become familiar with Churchill's habits.

Highly recommend!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: At first, I was overwhelmed by the book's length and smaller print. Oh, would I ever read it? finish it? Well, I just did and as I was getting to the end, I realized how much I was enjoying the book and how much I learned. We all think we know a major figure like Churchill and, indeed, much of that came through. However, details about his first year+ as Prime Minister, his family, his office entourage, and the others with whom he surrounded himself, make for a fascinating read. Larson weaves quotes into his writing and makes it all turn out as incredibly readable prose. There are a great many details and I have heard it called a "textbook," but as there is no test or book report due, reading it as leisure reading is probably why I enjoyed it so much.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I never realized the length of the bombing of England, the death and destruction caused, how widespread in the country it was, and the amazing bravery of the people.
The Churchill portrait is also one that shared the strong connection between him and the people during this time. The parallel description of the Germans during this period gives it an exciting edginess.
The only thing that keeps from giving five stars is the time given to the Churchill family which I found frankly to be less than engaging and not necessary.
But read this book for the vivid portrait of a people under siege, most timely for all of us in these virus times.
titles: A story that resonates in these times

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Erik Larson is one of those nonfiction writers who can hold a fiction-reading audience firmly in his grasp, from beginning to end. The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz covers a relatively short period of time in British history, but every day is weighty and tense. As the daughter of a British mother and an American P-51 fighter pilot, I felt as if I were reading a part of their history they could never have explained so fully. Larson drives home the valor of the British people, the steadfast strength of their leaders, and the very human stories of the players behind the scenes. Highly recommended.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
There are volumes of information on Winston Churchill that chronicle his life. This book focuses on the first years of the blitzkrieg and him as Prime Minister. Even though we know how this war ended, the unfolding of events is an engaging read. The reader feels the urgency and weight of the difficult decision Churchill had to make. You feel the sadness and hopelessness of events out of Churchill's control, yet encouraged by his unfailing optimism. The story also contains many behind-the-scenes humor and pieces of everyday life.
I loved reading this and recommend its combination of history, psychology, and suspense.
Thank you #NetGalley and @RandomHouse for the eARC.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I found this book to be totally outstanding. Great story. characters you cared about. Wonderful descriptions. Occasionally very short chapters. ( OK. That isn't that important, but it enhanced the flow of the book ). If you enjoy history, especially WW II history, this book is one you should definitely check out. I will say the bad news is the book highlights what an inspirational leader does in a crisis. The comparison of that leadership with what we are experiencing from our current leader is not something one should dwell on too long. Five stars all the way. ( The book, not our current leader )
titles: Great Read for these Troubled Times

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Larson keeps going downhill and I hope he’s hit bottom now and starts writing quality books again. It’s as if he just decided to fill a book with uninteresting quotes from diaries. I learned nothing new about Churchill, but learned a lot about his daughter Mary and son Raymond, who both proved to be completely uninteresting. Every description of a night of bombing was described so similarly that the book became torture to read. Maybe if one knows nothing about Britain’s role from 1939-1941, this book might be interesting. But if you’re looking for a new angle on a fascinating character, Churchill,you won’t find it here. And all those quotes from diaries seemed like a way For Larson to get his word count up without doing any homework.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Once again Larson makes history come alive, this time choosing as his canvas the first year of Winston Churchill's tenure as Prime Minister, during the Blitz. Military history is the background for an intimate portrait of Churchill and those in his orbit: family members, secretaries, and ministers alike. It's a rousing story combined with a nuanced character study.

The book is a captivating tale of a period of crisis and the remarkable person perfectly suited to handling it.

(I read an advance copy provided by the publisher through NetGalley.)
titles: I feel this is Larson's best book yet

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
As always, Erik Larson came through again with an interesting and well-written book.
Another reviewer made a comment about copying and pasting entries from diaries, interviews, etc but that is precisely why I love Erik Larson books. He does so much research and provides so much detail that I can't help but get engrossed in the history and personalities.
I will add that my book spine was not very sturdy either though the pages were good. No matter, I usually buy two copies anyway of my favourite books in case one goes belly up or drops in a puddle.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I looked forward to this book, having read the same author's "Devil in the White City," "Thunderstruck," "In the Garden of Beasts" and "Dead Wake," but this one isn't a patch on his previous work. It jumps all over the place, spends a lot of time on trivia and reads like a compilation of leftover notes from some other book. Quite disappointing.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: "The Splendid and the Vile" started out strong, chronicling Churhill's first days in office. Also, the author kept strict chronological order giving specific dates at every turn; a technique more historians should follow as it dramatically aids comprehension. Unfortunately the book became very repetitive as England struggled for over a year with constant bombing raids. Perhaps if the author had focused more on the amazing successes of the RAF or had more detailed information on the vast support from the U.S., the book would not have faltered. By the end, excessive trivia and repetition defeated all interest in Churchill's family, friends and working relationships.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: A wonderful book about the first year of the war in the UK - or to be more exact, during Churchill's first year as PM. This book is centered in Churchill and his close circle (family and friends) rather than the war as a whole - both topics are intertwined though, being Churchill PM and having placed some of his friends at the top echelons of the British government. It offers little insight into the German side of the war but there is a lot about the RAF and the bombings in London and the fight in the skies. Well research and reads easily.
titles: Great book about the first year of Churchill as PM during WWII

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Very good book for the day to day coverage of Churchill's first year (approx) as PM. a few "nits order of you have got to be to be kidding: NO mention of Bertram Ramsay who conceived of, and managed the Dunkirk evacuation; did not give Dowding near enough credit for the BoB victory, heck no credit at all really. He conceived of and operationalized the whole defense system: radar, controllers, etc. and managed his forces brilliantly. He should be standing next to Nelson on top of TS.; and no mention of the sinking of the Bismark and loss of the Hood; -referred to the BF109 as the ME109 (rookie error),
titles: very good book but a few oversights and issues

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Fascinating and very well written. Such a timely story, given the challenges that america faces today. An intimate window into what a truly great leader is capable of in times of crisis. The book takes you back to day to day life in london during one of its darkest periods. You get to know Winston Churchill not only as the incredible, unifying leader that he was, but also as a husband, father, and citizen.
America could really use a Winston Churchill-type leader right now. Read this and you'll truly understand why.

Fantastic book.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This is a very dense book, packing a lot into the story of the first year of Churchill's reign as prime minister and the start of the War against Germany and Great Britain. There are quite a few characters to keep track of, a lot of British government folk I didn't know much about before now. I really liked how Larson added quite a bit from personal diaries, in particular Mary Churchill (their youngest child) and the Mass Observation diaries kept by regular Brits during the war. Another good book with solid historical detail.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: You can find many more knowledgeable reviews about this than mine. Most of what I learned before this book about Churchill and the Blitz came from novels. But here is something I can tell you. I started reading the book out loud to my husband during the Beginning Note to the Reader and I didn’t stop. There is so much interesting information. If you love WWII English fiction, read this book. Larson’s writing often feels like fiction, but it is a non-fiction book. It may be one of the best books I read in 2020.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I am a major fan of Larson’s books and enjoy his focus on the personal In major historical events. My two regrets are The lack of photos and the lack of any full speeches or radio broadcasts. Photos would have brought certainly relatively unknown characters to life. Larson gives us nicely paraphrased summaries and key snippets from major speeches, but at least one full quote would have helped. I note that, at he end of the Audible version, we hear the recording if Winston’s Xmas speech during his 1941 trip to meet with FDR in DC. Great addition!
titles: Disappointed with no photos and no full speeches

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
This is a very engaging and compelling examination of Great Britain's role as the last line of defense against Hitler's Nazi Germany, with a particular focus on Winston Churchill, his family, and his professional inner circle. In this book, Larson focuses on a pivotal twelve-month period (May 1940 to May 1941); this narrow focus enables him to delve more fully into the idiosyncrasies and human frailties of the principal decision-makers and those around them. Ironically, by demythologizing Churchill, his family, and his coterie of advisors and confidants, he ends up pointing up their extraordinary courage, persistence, prudence, and pragmatism--virtues which persist despite the fact that these were human beings under immense pressure.

The fact that this book presents Churchill and others as fully-drawn characters also makes the work compellingly readable--this is most certainly not a dry tome of mere dates, death tolls, or technical minutia. My only critique of the book is that there occasionally seemed to be too much detail on tertiary and quaternary characters, but in many cases they eventually ended up being tied back into the main narrative thread, so the attention was mostly justified even though the story seems to wander a bit afield at times.

If readers are looking for a comprehensive history of World War II, or even of England's role in World War II, they will likely be disappointed, but readers seeking a focused window into the personality, thinking and decision-making processes, virtues, and idiosyncrasies of Winston Churchill and those around him will find this an engaging, fascinating, and absorbing read.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I'm a big Larson fan and a WW2 nerd, so I had high expectations for this book. Absolutely loved it though. It is fascinating to read about the almost daily life of England's fearless leader in Churchill during one of the most stressful/horrific periods in British history - the German Blitz of 1940/41.

I appreciate that Larson spends almost as much time on the characters surrounding Churchill - including his daughter, wife, son, and children-in-law. Also plenty of great stories about his cabinet, closest advisers, friends, and others who were close to the PM during this time. The little stories Larson is able to pull from journals, other biographies and documentation are so wonderful and telling - they reveal the quirky and endearing, but more often than not, the overpowering and commanding personality of Churchill.

In my opinion, other than DitWC, this is likely Larson's best work so far.
titles: Brilliantly researched (as always) and compelling story at a human level

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Extraordinary! I've added all the rest of Erik Larson's books to my list. He is a wonderful storyteller. I found myself really looking forward to any minute I could steal to read this. A fascinating look at Churchill's first year as Prime Minister. Certainly put my problems in perspective! Very well researched and yet very entertaining. A real page turner. I'm sorry it ended. I am ever so grateful to have received an advance copy in exchange for my honest review.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Erik Larson is a great historical non fiction writer and this book is a perfect example of that. The Splendid And The Vile is a real page turner about a subject that is well known to most of us.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
A fact filled account of UK life and leadership of Churchill. Anecdotes and stories from supporting characters share the drama and day to day challenges of life during the blitz from the carnage and destruction to how the upper classes of être dined and danced the night away during the blitz.
Very well researched and documented. Is an extraordinarily detailed look at how the Brits fought back against overwhelming odds. Highly recommend this book.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Once again Erik Larson makes you feel you were you were actually there, experiencing Churchhill's finest hour as he leads his people during the darkest hours of WW2. The incredible resilience of the English people, especially residents of London during relentless bombing attacks is courageously depicted. Churchill is revealed as reveling in leading his country in such a difficult time, while humbled by the faith his people
Have in him.And the Battle of Britain is ultimately won by the Royal Air Force, which denies Hitler the air superiority he needed for an invasion.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: 'The Splendid and the Vile" by Erik Larson is a marvelous book! Larson captures the tenor and urgency of 194o/41 in Great Britain about as well as one can. Seen through the eyes of Winston Churchill, his family, key members of his staff and government; as well as a few key German foes, Larson portrays one of the most important times of the twentieth century. The characters and story jump to life in this book and I cannot recommend it enough!
titles: Critical history brought vividly to life!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
This account of Churchill’s first year as Prime Minister makes extensive use of diary entries of the various participants surrounding him. It makes one wonder what future historians will glean of our times with the vast amount of digital data we generate.

My only criticism of the book is that in the afterword where the author details the later lives of the various participants he neglects to tell us what happened to Nelson.
titles: Excellent account that puts you in London during the Blitz

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I am a history lover and thought this would be a good read because I've enjoyed many of Larsen's books. I didn't realize how much I didn't know. One of the best things about this author's books is his vast research. I must say I was not as knowledgable as I thought.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Not my favorite Larson book, most of which I've enjoyed. And while I like descriptive writing, this just seemed to bog down in the details, especially when it jumped from one story/person/incident to another. It was all over the place and, frankly, at times boring and tedious. I think it would have been more interesting and readable if he had condensed it a bit. It's a fascinating story and period in history, though - and I appreciate it for that.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Such a well-written book. History the Erik Larson way reads like great fiction.

The extensive notes show how much research goes into his books.

I'd only known headlines about Churchill. This is a much deeper dive, not only into him, but those around him. I got a real appreciation of the man who saved Britain in WW2, even with no shortage of setbacks.

And then the detail on his family, friends, subordinates, it all paints a deeply detailed picture.

500+ pages, and when you're finished, you wish there was more.
titles: A detailed look at Churchill - and Britain - under fire

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This chronically of Churchill’s first year as Prime Minister contains no surprises. It joins the other uncritical biographies that make a hero out of the wartime political leader. Larson has made a career out of this kind of history lite. I guess if you are looking for something that does not distract from hero worship, this is or you. However, the Battle of Britain is reduced to hundreds of pages of anecdotes and adoration.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have been reading this book during the current corona virus scare in New York State. What a perfect antidote to the panic here. The courage and fortitude of all the British people defies belief. I discovered from this book that my parents married during the darkest days of the war 31March 1941 and the details of the trip that my Uncle Bob the train driver who drove the train to take Churchill to Scapa Flow. A wonderful and therapeutic experience. One criticism Erik please do not interchange England with Britain. England is not synonymous with Britain that insults Scotland Wales and Northern Ireland.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: If this is the only book you have ever read by Erik Larson, I recommend all of them. Isaac's Storm puts you right in the middle of Galveston's 1900 hurricane, The Devil in the White city pulls you in during the Chicago Exposition while exposing a serial killer, and The Garden of the Beast is a piece you can't put down. That is just a few of his books. His research is thorough and historically accurate in my opinion.
titles: If you love history, you will love love this!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
The world of London and Winston Churchill comes gloriously to life in this account gleaned from Churchill's records and diaries from those around him.
These chapters alternate with exploring Hitler's Germany and those in conflict with Hitler's vile reign. Erik Larson is masterful at showing Winston Churchill's humanity, strong leadership, and why he is credited with saving democracy.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I love historical fiction, and Larson made this more interesting than most other non-fiction books. The fact that I was 6 months old when my father left to help fight WWII made it that much more interesting for me. The use of quotes and diary entries, along with plenty of research made this far more than "just history". Only 4 stars because I did not need all the "love affairs".

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Easy to read; not a complete bio, but focused on his time as PM during WWII. A GREAT READ.
I was surprised to read of so many personal / private conversations & sidelines, I'm guessing they were gleaned from memoirs & other accounts previously published or at least available to researchers...
I read Devil in the White City, they each rate my Highest recommendations.
titles: I could have read this in One Sit...

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Packed with Interesting Details... A (relatively) Fast Paced Page Turner. The hardbound text is some 500 pages but it goes fast. A bit wordy in parts (that didn't interest me) but easy to skim to capture the interesting details of Churchill, the Family, The Air War and the people that made the British victory possible and Germany's defeat inevitable....
titles: You get a Front Seat to the Action...  --AND the Drama!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This book could have been written in half the number of words and details. I usually like Larson books but this one just boggles the mind. At about 20% I began to skim read and by the end, i was just tapping the pages to get through. If you really love war history and lots of details, then you’d probably like this, not me. The epilogue is good.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I've always liked Larson's books but it wasn't until Dead Wake that I loved one of his books. So I was curious if this would be another good book of his or another amazing one like Dead Wake. I can say now it's the latter. This is an excellent book on Churchill. The right man in the right place at the right time.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This seems the book about Churchill for those who may have already read a half dozen of them. While the author attempted to make Mary Churchill and John Colville characters to stimulate the narrative, neither was strong enough to maintain it. Many places big down with minutiae- some of interest, some not.
titles: Good but lacking a central narrative

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Real page turner. Covers about the first year of Churchill's tenure as Prime Minister. Made me want to read more about this fascinating, multi-faceted man. Notes in back of book contain additional details and are unique in that they reference not only the chapter but page number as well. Hated for it to end.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I’ll start by saying I was already a big fan of Erik Larson. I love his writing style, interspersing historical events with greater depth into the characters involved. The Splendid and the Vile is another great example. He gives you a lot of perspective about Churchill and those close to him during the period of the Blitz - in many cases pulling from their personal diaries. I learned so much, and he’s inspired me to research a few people and events I want to know more about. I’m going to add a few of his titles I’ve not yet read to my cart.
titles: Another great read by one of my favorite authors

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Wonderful ,personalized history of Churchill and his part in WW Two. Couldn't put it down, flowed right along. With all the personal stories and insites on Churchill, it made this part of history seem more alive. With all his books, Erik Larson wants you to think as well...and in my case, I become more curious about the subject matter and go after additional information . Great book.
titles: Another extraordinary book by Erik Larson

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Having recently finished "Atlantic Nighmare" regarding the WWII battles at sea, this book filled in the other side for the battle of the air. But of more interest were the personal stories around Churchill, his family and colleagues during the extremely trying first year of the war.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
I read a free sample and enjoyed the read. Has slightly too much frivolous dialogue about personal idiosyncrasies of
Mr. Churchill and the other characters but in all a good read.

These guys are having a laugh trying to charge $15 for an e-book. Ha Ha...
titles: Great Book but will never pay $15 for ebook.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I enjoyed the book and learned more about Churchill and World War II. For me 500 pages was a bit too long for the information provided. I did enjoy many of the personal diary information obtained by the author. There was more information on the daughter Mary that I cared to learn and yet not enough information on Winston spouse Clementine. Overall a bit of a slow read (much of that due to the length of book) but I did find overall enjoyable.
titles: Interesting but a bit too long for information provided

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Erik Larson is the master at historical research and turning it into reading like a novel. Churchill really came alive. We all know him as a great orator, and parts of his famous speeches are shared, but we learned about how he led and lived. For example, he spent every weekend surrounded by his top lieutenants at the weekend home where they would dine fairly lavishly, drink lots of brandy, smoke cigars and he would keep them up till the wee hours of the morning talking about the war and other things. He loved to hear what other people thought - great trait of leaders, and then make the decisions. Lots more like this.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Erik Larson could write a phone book and it would be a best seller. He is the greatest author I have experienced. Love the story and facts about Churchill that I never knew. God bless all those who had to live though this terrible war.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Larson does it again. He does the necessary research to illuminate this critical period and he tells the story in an entertaining manner. I thought I knew quite a bit about this period but this brings so much more to light. Well done!
titles: Fascinating look at a crucial time in modern history

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Captivating telling of the time and characters during the Blitz on London. Best book I've read so far this year. It's a book about a historical event and time but it is not dry and a hard read like some books about history are.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I am a huge fan of history books, especially books about the Battle of Britain. This is BY FAR the best book I have ever read on the subject. Erik Larson has crafted a true page-turner that captures both the historical narrative (with a few instances where long-held urban myths are shattered) as well as a intimate portrayal of Winston Churchill and his family. Reading this book was one of the highlights of the COVID quarantine for me!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: A fascinating, novelistic book about Winston Churchill that's more colorful and easier to read, though just as verifiable accurate, as most of the more academic biographies of a compelling historical figure.
titles: Extraordinary - The Subject, the Author and the Book

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I’ve read most of Erik Larson’s books and enjoyed all of them. But this account of World War II from the Churchill’s perspective is a stand out. It is somehow inspiring and uplifting in the present uncertain times of the pandemic. Highly recommended. I would read it again, which places it on my A List.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I absolutely LOVED this book. Such a neat perspective and very cool insight. I love how his writing style draws me in and can make me interested in topics that previously held no interest for me.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Sad day! The book ended. It read like a mystery novel that I just wanted to keep reading to see how it ended! I have read every book written by Erik Larson and this one did not disappoint me at all.
titles: What a great book on Churchill!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I applaud the detail and research that went into this book. As if present, Erik Larson transports the reader to the dramatic and even routine events unfolding in Churchill’s life and Great Britain in 1940. We relive this pivotal year that sorely tested the survival of a great nation.
titles: A journey of survival, persistence, and resistance

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: A fascinating look inside the Churchill family and the others whose lives they touched during the Nazi bombing of Britain, as well as views of Churchill from the perspective of Hitler and his advisors. For such a well researched and oft written of subject, Winston Churchill, it is very difficult to take a unique approach. But Larson has done it, and done it well.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: An in depth look at the first year of Winston Churchill as Prime Minister of Britain. There were many anecdotes which provided a valuable insight into the war and Churchill.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I am a big Larson fan, but don't think this book is quite up to his previous standards. A bit too repetitive and with too much detail at times; but still a pretty good read.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I am a big fan of Erik Larson and gave read most of his books and thoroughly enjoyed them. Not so in this case! The first half was interesting to a point; but re-hashing Mary dancing her way through one bombing run after another in between tedious and boring! I'll be more cautious about investing (both time and money) in another Larson book.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I usually like Larsen's books but this one was a disappointment. I did not admire Churchill after this account of his eccentric pink silk underwear, hot baths every day and long naps. At least the chapters were short. And Churchill's children did not fare well in their stories either. I guess he is a hero because he outlived everyone else from WW 11.
titles: Not the best  story of Churchill

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Erik Larson has done it again! His in depth scholarship blended with his incredible ability to make non-fiction come alive with suspense makes this Churchill-centric work a wonderful read. I am well versed in World Warn II history, but the drama of this dangerous time mixed with an in depth look at the Churchill family and the main characters of the one year battle brought me a new and deeper understanding of 1940-41 Britain.
titles: A Brilliant and Uniquely Personal Take on England During the Blitz

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Larson’s weakest book yet. The sections (and there are a lot) with Mary are skimmable, if not outright skippable, without losing an ounce of the story and are a distraction from the main story— which is Churchill vs. Germany. 3 stars seems too low while 4 seems too high—thus I’m only rating this 4 stars based off Larson’s body of work and how highly readable the Churchill sections are.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I loved this book but the ending was too sudden. I realize the author was focused on a certain period of Churchill’s life and career, but many threads are created and not fully resolved. Still a terrific book.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: as the headline suggests, i found that Disc 09 in the CD set, is actually Disc 10. Windows Media Player even listed Disc 09 as "Disc 10" when it was playing from my computer. I'm not sure if all of the CD Sets are this way, but i thought i'd put it out there. we got it from the library, and we will be letting them know whenever we return it.
titles: Audiobook CDs - Disc 09 is actually Disc 10, and Disc 10 is actually Disc 09

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have actually never read a “bad” Erik Larsen book, and I can tell you this one is indeed “splendid”. His books are always extremely well researched and written. This one is no exception. Even in its “unedited” form (I read the galley version) I can predict this will be a best seller as he chronicles Winston Churchill and his leadership through Britain’s darkest days.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: The subject matter is fascinating. Larson always has a different take on a Historical event. Don’t love his writing style in this one though. Most surpri thing about Churchill is his dancing and singing late into the night.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Crashes Kindle Fire @ about 7 %. Could go to other chapters with “Go To” but could not read crashed section. Kindle chat assisted and attempted reload and reboot but no joy. All other recent downloads are crash-free, suggesting code problem in the software. Amazon provided refund. Need to know when the problem is fixed.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I am a high-schooler, and this book was a real page-turner. It was hard to put it down after I started—the pacing and character development is so well done! Would recommend to practically anyone.
titles: Among the top 3 books I've ever read

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This really is a great book. It holds your interest throughout. The author as obviously done intensive research to bring some of the details to the "story" he tells. Highly recommended.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I was excited about this book as I love his writing. This was a bit of a slow disappointment in comparison. Didn't love it.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This book had over 100 chapters but each wasn’t very long. I found the authors style easy to read and I couldn’t put the book down.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: truly puts being locked at home during COVID in perspective. Larsen is a great writer and this one is a page turner.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
The resiliency of the British people is just astounding. It gives me hope for what we are going through right now. The pandemic pales in comparison to what they went through.

I wish President Trump would some pages from Churchill's playbook.
titles: Great read during the COVID-19 pandemic

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Nothing new here. But it’s a stirring tale, and Larson tells it well, full of entertaining anecdotes.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: The story of the London Blitz and of Winston Churchill's leadership was a joy to read. I thought I knew the story quite well, but I learned much from Erik Larson's "splendid" writing.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This is a grand look at Churchill as a real person. Anyone who intends to vote in November should read this. It’s a clear illustration of what leadership means and how it manifests.
titles: Typifies why I love reading Larson

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This was my first Eric Larson book, and really my first book focused on Churchill. I absolutely loved this book. As others have said, it reads like a fictional novel even though it's 100% non-fiction. I have a whole new appreciation for Churchill, his leadership style and the incredibly difficult times England went through.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Well so far. I have it on my kindle and that is one of my activities during the lock down.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I believe the other five star reviews said it better than I can. But for my two cents I have to say I had gotten way more than I expected. I was mostly interested in the blitz but Winston Churchill’s part in it took it to a new level. Thank you. James ODonohoe.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have read hundreds of books on World War 2 and this ranks as one of the most enjoyable. My only regret was that it wasn’t three or four times longer. The research is impeccable and the story-telling superb.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I truly enjoy reading Erik Larson’s books. His style of writing is artful and informative, but easy to read. This book takes a fresh look at some of the personal lives of Churchill, his family, and his aides. It is definitely a book for someone who is a fan of history!
titles: Excellent read! Fascinating personal look at Churchill!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Love this book. I wish it included photos though. Other than that, it is awesome!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I always enjoy reading Eric Larson. He works hard to present facts, not fiction.
titles: Once again, a fantastic book from Larson

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: The story of the suffering of the English people in this time is inspiring.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Recycles only information about the times we knew already...for a better grip read Korda and Lucas

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I greatly enjoyed this tremendous look into Churchill and the Blitz. While lengthy, it flew by and Larson’s writing style really made this read engrossing.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This is an excellent portrayal of Churchill’s personal life. The book illustrates how his personal life informs his decisions and relationships, such as the critically important relationship with Lord Beaverbrook.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I watched on C-SPAN his talk for this book. It is the most vacuous thing ever.
titles: This may be the worst book ever written about Churchill

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I have read most of Erik Larson's books and liked them very much. Enjoyed Devil in the White City, In the Garden of Beasts. I was very disappointed in this book. It is way to long and I thought it was boring. Couldn't even finish the book, which is unusual for me.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I loved this book! Larson's narrative of the story of Churchill and the Battle of Britain reads like an action-packed novel. The personalities of the very real characters, gripping (and even humorous) situations, and unbelievable view of behind-the-scenes drama added up to a great read.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Reads like a novel, gives you detailed history the way you always wished it would be, using primary sources written by the people who lived through the period, and limns a portrait of Churchill with depth and conviction.
titles: Best biography of Churchill during the blitz.  Most highly tevommended.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: What I found so engaging about Larson's earlier works are missing here. I think he may have bitten off more than he can chew, given how much has already been written about Churchill and the relevant times. SUMMARY: Past works... Hurrah! This book.... Meh.
titles: Certainly not vile, but not so splendid.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This was an overly-narrow focus on the personal minutia of the first years of Winston Churchill's term as Prime Minister; one might as well have just read the society gossip columns from the era. Very little substance, too much the privilege of the British upper class.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Erik Larson is a master at taking mountains of research and turning it into an interesting read. This new look at Churchill once again shows us all that he was the right man in the right job at the right time.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
*****
Excellent read about the personal effect of war by the brave, resilient British people under the most excellent wartime leader, bar none. Great book and good literate distraction during the corona virus pandemic of 2020. It rained down deadly germs not bombs.

D.L.
Boston
titles: Reading of the personal effect of war during a health pandemic crisis......

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I would really like the reviews to be in chronological order please.
titles: Why aren't the reviews in chronological order.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents:
Didn’t think we needed another book (Movie) about Churchill or the Battle of Britain.

Boy - was I wrong. Couldn’t put it down. Read like a thriller.

Glad Highwood librarian recommended it.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: A true story that reads like fiction. It's terrific.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Audible version enjoyable.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Larsen’s book makes great reading for fans of The Great Man. It adds some tasty morsels to the saga of a 20th century giant.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Erik Larson has a way of writing historical works of non-fiction that bring the events to life. This is a different side of Churchill that I have never read about and it includes his family life.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I am a big Larson fan and loved his other books. This one was easily my least favorite. The history is solid and its an easy read like his others but lacked the jam of Devil in the White City and Dead Wake.
titles: Good book. Not as good as his others.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This book was too long and too much effort for me to read the whole book, i would rather read Lincoln rhyme

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Larson provides a fresh look at London during the Blitz and a fresh portrait of Churchill and his inner circle, written in the way that only he can.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: As usual, well researched and detailed. A look behind the legend of WWII Churchill. As good as the other Larson books.
titles: Another fascinating book by Erik Larson

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Great backstory and insights into WC’s personal life. Enjoyed the perspective of his young daughter, Mary and her lack of experience.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Amazing in detail and research yet close and personal. It feels like Larson could have been one of Churchill’s entourage.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I thought this book was his best yet, even better than the Devil and the White City. I highly recommend it.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: A well written account of the years of Churchill’s years as prime minister, the war and all the people around him
titles: Excellent- nonfiction that reads like a novel

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Learned things we would not have otherwise, but seems to rush to an end, glossing over the attack on Russia and Pearl Harbor.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Such a comfort to read during the quarantine. Really helped put things in perspective.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: This book is a fantastic read.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: A masterpiece.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Excellent read!!!
titles: Couldn’t put it down. Best book I’ve read in years!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: One of Larson's best books to date. Packed with historical gems. Highly recommend.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Outstanding account of the period. And wonderfully written.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: I enjoyed this book.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: Fantastic Read! As a WWII history novice, this book read like a screenplay. It was enjoyable, an easy read, and Larson created all characters interesting & educational! It was such an interesting and enjoyable experience reading this book. It goes well beyond a typical history book. It read like an amazing story! Mr. Larson, thank you for this book!

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: McCullough, McPherson, Chernow, Goodwin, Meacham-these authors are among the greats of non fiction history books, and included among them, I place Eric Larson. Having read Dead Wake, I looked forward to The Splendid and the Vile.His thorough research and writing style make the reader feel transposed from the couch in the living room to the shelters of London during the German blitz.And holding the British nation together, giving its people hope, was Winston Churchill, he with odd quirks of dress (or undress!), liquor (lots of brandy), derring do (standing on roofs of buildings while bombs fell), but so emotionally invested with the people and their plight, that his tears often flowed. His great speechs, relationship with FDR, dire need for American help, all noted, yet so are the thoughts of his daughter, Mary, who hated the war, worshiped her father, but seemed to have many happy times with parties and dances, his wife Clementine, his confidant and advisor, who always seemed to have a cold, the love life of family and those who worked for him including Averell Harriman, the love he had for his rather poor excuse of a gambling, argumentative, disliked by many son Randolph and the graphic descriptions of death and destruction. Uppermost in my mind on this last is his description of a dog wandering about carrying a child's arm in its mouth. In times of great need, the best seem to come to the fore - the American founding fathers, Abe Lincoln, both Roosevelts, perhaps Gorbachev in Russia, Mandela, Nehru. Meanwhile, the United States is now waiting and wanting for a people loving, nation loving savior to come forth and restore our republic to its once greatness.

product_name: The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family, and Defiance During the Blitz
review_contents: It's been some time since I have read a book of history that has been so compelling. It's not that the author has revealed new or startling information. It's not as if we don't know the ending before we start reading. Larson's contribution to this effort is his ability to give the reader a sense of what it was like to have been in Britain during those beginning months of the War. We are able to understand how and why the citizenry had the stamina and fortitude to withstand the blitzekrieg, losses of lives, lack of daily sustenances, and thereby confound the enemy. Let us not consider what might have happened had they been less resilient.
titles: An explanation of British resiliency and stamina
